metadata.case_name: Allahabad Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Workmen (Bijli Mazdoor Sangh)

facts.text: The appellant, a limited liability company which later went into voluntary liquidation, was carrying on the business of generation, distribution and supply of electricity, including the Electric Supply Undertaking at Allahabad managed by Martin Burn Co. Ltd., Calcutta.
Some of the appellant's workmen in Allahabad and surrounding area were members of Bijli Mazdoor Sangh, a trade union registered under the Indian Trade Union Act, 1926.
U.P. State Electricity Board compulsorily acquired and took over the assets of the appellant's undertaking with effect from 16/17th September 1964.

Appellant submitted draft Standing Orders under Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act 1946 and U.P. Rules 1946; certified by Certifying Officer on July 14, 1951. Clause 32: 'RETIREMENT-An employee who has served 30 years or who has reached the age of 55 will be retired, but exemption to this may be granted by the Company in special cases.'
Workmen through Bijli Mazdoor Sangh appealed under s.6 of the Act to State Industrial Tribunal; appeal dismissed.
Similar certified Standing Orders for Agra Electric Supply Co. Ltd. and Benaras Electric Light & Power Co. Ltd. (appellant in connected C.A. 164/68).

On July 16, 1959, notices served on seven workmen (Respondents 1-6 and Haider Ali, deceased during proceedings) retiring them with effect from September 1, 1959, on ground of attaining superannuation age or completing 30 years service.
Workmen accepted Provident Fund accumulations and gratuities credited for service prior to PF membership.

Government of U.P. referred dispute under s.4-K U.P. Industrial Disputes Act 1946 to Industrial Tribunal-I Allahabad: 'Whether the employers have wrongfully and/or unjustifiably retired their workmen... with effect from 1st August, 1959? If so, to what relief?' (Annexure listed Respondents 1-6 and Haider Ali).

Workmen's case: Entered service before certification; no condition of retirement at prescribed age/period at appointment; practice was continuance till physically unfit; Clause 32 not binding/enforceable.
Industrial Tribunal award dated May 2, 1960: Employers within rights; retirement not wrongful/illegal/unjustified; no relief.
Bijli Mazdoor Sangh applied under s.10(2) for amendment of Clause 32 to fix retirement at 60 years (June 14, 1960).
Union filed writ petition in Allahabad High Court to quash award (September 20, 1960).
Certifying Officer modified Clause 32, fixed retirement age at 58 years (April 22, 1961).
Appellate authority refixed age at 55 years (September 10, 1961). Similar orders for Agra and Banaras companies.
Allahabad High Court quashed award on July 12, 1966, holding Standing Order 32 not applicable to employees before certification, relying on Guest Keen Williams; directed Tribunal to rehear.

Industrial Tribunal final award May 19, 1967: Seven workmen wrongfully retired; deemed continued till September 16, 1964 (takeover); pay full wages Aug 1, 1959 to Sep 16, 1964 + retrenchment compensation u/s 25F r/w 25FF & 25J ID Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether certified Standing Orders apply to workmen employed prior to certification.
Whether Clause 32 relating to retirement/superannuation could be validly certified in July 1951, absent specific item in Schedule.
What is the appropriate age of superannuation for the workmen concerned.
Whether High Court order quashing award operates as res judicata.

petitioner_arguments.text: Certified Standing Orders bind employers and all workmen in employment at time of certification and thereafter as uniform conditions of service.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act 1946 ss.3,4,5,6,7,9,10; Agra Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Sri Alladin (1970)

petitioner_arguments.text: Clause 32 validly certified; Schedule item 8 (termination of employment) covers retirement/superannuation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Schedule to 1946 Act; Management of the Hindu, Madras v. Secretary Hindu (AIR 1961 Mad 107)

petitioner_arguments.text: Post-1956 amendment, uniformity of conditions contemplated; Guest Keen Williams distinguished as pre-amendment.

respondent_arguments.text: Standing Orders not applicable to employees who entered service before certification; practice was continuance till physically unfit.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Guest Keen Williams Pvt. Ltd. v. P.J. Sterling (1960 1 SCR 348)

respondent_arguments.text: No item in Schedule for retirement/superannuation till item 11-C introduced Nov 17, 1959; Clause 32 invalid as certified 1951.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Schedule to 1946 Act; Saroj Kumar Ghosh v. Orissa State Electricity Board (AIR 1970 Ori 126)

respondent_arguments.text: High Court order quashing award final, bars reconsideration by res judicata.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Management of Northern Railway Cooperative Society Ltd. v. Industrial Tribunal (1967 2 SCR 476)

court_reasoning.text: Certified Standing Orders post-1956 amendment bind all workmen including those employed before certification to ensure uniformity; distinguishes Guest Keen (pre-amendment, limited Certifying Officer role); follows Agra Electric and Salem Erode.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object of Act defeated if different conditions for pre/post certification employees; leads to unrest.

court_reasoning.text: Clause 32 invalid in 1951: No Schedule item (8/9 not cover superannuation, automatic event unlike termination); pre-1956 s.4 barred fairness check.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Certifying Officer function limited to Schedule matters and model conformity.

court_reasoning.text: Valid after modification April 22, 1961 (age 58); fixes superannuation at 58 years for these workmen as fair/reasonable per Certifying Officer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal can determine age notwithstanding certified clause.

court_reasoning.text: High Court remand order interlocutory, not res judicata; proceedings terminated by final award.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes Northern Railway; follows Satyadhyan Ghosal.

holdings.text: Certified Standing Orders apply to all workmen employed before or after certification.
Clause 32 as certified July 1951 invalid and not binding.
Age of superannuation for concerned workmen is 58 years.
High Court remand order does not attract res judicata.

precedents_cited.case_name: Guest Keen Williams Pvt. Ltd. v. P.J. Sterling
precedents_cited.relevance: Pre-1956 amendment; Standing Orders not binding on pre-certification employees; Tribunal can fix age.

precedents_cited.case_name: Workmen of Kettlewell Bullen Co. Ltd. v. Kettlewell Bullen Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Guest Keen on non-applicability to existing employees.

precedents_cited.case_name: Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd. v. Employees' Union
precedents_cited.relevance: No scope for separate Standing Orders for different employee groups; uniformity required.

precedents_cited.case_name: Agra Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Sri Alladin
precedents_cited.relevance: Standing Orders bind existing and future employees; uniformity principle.

precedents_cited.case_name: Saroj Kumar Ghosh v. Orissa State Electricity Board
precedents_cited.relevance: Certification invalid if clause not covered by Schedule.

precedents_cited.case_name: Management of the Hindu, Madras v. Secretary Hindu Office National Press Employees' Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Item 8 covers superannuation; dissented from by Orissa HC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Management of Northern Railway Cooperative Society Ltd. v. Industrial Tribunal Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Res judicata on final writ dismissal.
Remand orders interlocutory, no res judicata.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs certification, applicability, modification of Standing Orders; pre/post-1956 amendment roles of Certifying Officer.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Retrenchment compensation on takeover; distinguishes retrenchment from superannuation.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Tribunal award set aside. Workmen deemed continued in service till attaining age 58 years; entitled to full wages and dues till then. Adjustments for prior payments; no refund claims by appellant. No costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Full wages and dues till age 58; adjustment of prior payments.

key_quotes.text: "the object of the Act is to certify Standing Orders in respect of all the matters covered by the schedule and having regard to these matters Standing Orders so certified would be uniform and would apply to all Workmen alike who are employed in any industrial establishment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on uniformity of Standing Orders.

key_quotes.text: "If any other result were to follow there would be different conditions of employment for different classes of workmen which would render the conditions of their service as indefinite and diversified as before the enactment of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose of legislation against discriminatory conditions.

key_quotes.text: "clause 32 of the Standing Orders as certified in July 1951 was not valid and cannot be binding on the respondents."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key finding on invalidity of original Clause 32.
